title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Secretary must consult with states and define hazardous agents as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act mandates the development of protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Act defines dangerous biological agents and chemicals, with the latter requiring the Secretary to create a list of known substances within 45 days. The Hazard Investigation Board, as mandated by the Clean Air Act, must develop a list of chemicals known to cause serious harm to human health. Specific protocols for hazardous agents must be created, tailored to each agent unless deemed unnecessary by the Secretary. The Secretary must establish priorities for hazardous agents within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Protocols for the highest priority agent must be developed promptly within 45 days. The Secretary must ensure uniformity, testing, and other provisions for all protocols. The Secretary must promptly develop protocols for hazardous agents, ensuring uniformity, testing, and other provisions for public health emergencies. This includes coordinating with emergency response personnel, providing information to individuals at affected sites, testing and treating affected individuals, and decontaminating sites. The Secretary must periodically review and revise protocols for hazardous agents, with exemptions for existing protocols that meet requirements. A report listing exempt hazardous agents must be submitted to Congress within 30 days of enactment.
